sentences: Joe Logan Diffie (December 28, 1958 – March 29, 2020) was an American country music singer and songwriter.
section: N/A

sentences: After working as a demo singer in the mid 1980s, he signed with Epic Records' Nashville division in 1990.
section: N/A

sentences: Between then and 2004, Diffie charted 35 singles on the Billboard Hot Country Songs chart, five of which peaked at number one: his debut release "Home", "If the Devil Danced (In Empty Pockets)", "Third Rock from the Sun", "Pickup Man" (his longest-lasting number-one song, at four weeks) and "Bigger Than the Beatles".
section: N/A

sentences: In addition to these singles, he had 12 others reach the top 10 and ten more reach the top 40 on the same chart.
section: N/A

sentences: He also co-wrote singles for Holly Dunn, Tim McGraw, and Jo Dee Messina, and recorded with Mary Chapin Carpenter, George Jones, and Marty Stuart.
section: N/A

sentences: Diffie released seven studio albums, a Christmas album, and a greatest-hits package under the Epic label.
section: N/A

sentences: He also released one studio album each through Monument Records, Broken Bow Records, and Rounder Records.
section: N/A

sentences: Among his albums, 1993's Honky Tonk Attitude and 1994's Third Rock from the Sun are certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America, while 1992's Regular Joe and 1995's Life's So Funny are both certified gold.
section: N/A

sentences: His album, Homecoming: The Bluegrass Album, was released in late 2010 through Rounder.
section: N/A

sentences: His style is defined by a neotraditionalist country influence with a mix of novelty songs and ballads.
section: N/A

sentences: Diffie died due to complications related to COVID-19 during the pandemic on March 29, 2020, at the age of 61.
section: N/A
== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Joe Diffie was born into a musical family in Tulsa, Oklahoma, in 1958.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: His first musical performance came at age 7, when he performed in "The Muffin Man".
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Diffie's father, Joe R., played guitar and banjo, and his mother sang.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Following in his father's footsteps, Diffie began to sing at an early age, often listening to the albums in his father's record collection.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Diffie has said that his "Mom and Dad claimed that [he] could sing harmony when [he] was three years old."
section: == Early life ==

sentences: His family moved to San Antonio, Texas, while he was in the first grade, and subsequently to Washington, where he attended fourth and fifth grades.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Later, he moved to Wisconsin for the years he was in sixth grade through his second year of high school, and back to Oklahoma, where he attended high school in Velma.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: In his last two years in high school, Diffie played football, baseball, and golf in addition to running track; in his senior year, he was recognized as Best All-Around Male Athlete.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: After graduating, he attended Cameron University in Lawton, Oklahoma.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Although he initially earned credits toward medical school, he decided against a medical profession after marrying for the first time in 1977 and ultimately dropped out before graduation.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Diffie first worked in oil fields, then drove a truck that pumped concrete in the oilfield in Alice, Texas, before he moved back to Duncan to work in a foundry.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: During this period, he worked as a musician on the side, first in a gospel group called Higher Purpose, and then in a bluegrass band called Special Edition.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Diffie then built a recording studio, began touring with Special Edition in adjacent states, and sent demonstration recordings to publishers in Nashville.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Hank Thompson recorded Diffie's "Love on the Rocks", and Randy Travis put one of Diffie's songs on hold, but ultimately did not record it.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: After the foundry closed in 1986, Diffie declared bankruptcy and sold the studio out of financial necessity.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He also divorced his wife, who left with their two children.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Diffie spent several months in a state of depression before deciding to move to Nashville, Tennessee.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: There, he took a job at Gibson Guitar Corporation.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: While at Gibson, he contacted a songwriter and recorded more demos, including songs that would later be recorded by Ricky Van Shelton, Billy Dean, Alabama, and the Forester Sisters.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: By mid-1989, he quit working at the company  to record demos full-time.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Diffie also met Debbie, who later became his second wife.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: That same year, Diffie was contacted by Bob Montgomery, a songwriter and record producer known for working with Buddy Holly.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Montgomery, who was then the vice president of A&R at Epic Records, said that he wanted to sign Diffie to a contract with the label, but had to put the singer on hold for a year.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: In the meantime, Holly Dunn released "There Goes My Heart Again", which Diffie co-wrote and sang the backing vocals.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Following this song's chart success, Diffie signed with Epic in early 1990.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: In 1991, Diffie co-wrote the tracks "Livin' on What's Left of Your Love" and "Memory Lane" on labelmate Keith Palmer's debut album.

sentences: The first two singles from the album both peaked at number five on Billboard: "Is It Cold in Here" and "Ships That Don't Come In", with the latter reaching number one on Radio & Records.

section: == Professional music career == | === 1992: Regular Joe ===

sentences: Both of these songs made the country top 20, respectively reaching 16 and 15, and the duet was nominated for a Grammy Award for Best Country Collaboration with Vocals at the 35th Grammy Awards in 1993.

section: == Professional music career == | === 2004–2020: The Ultimate Collection and later activity ===

sentences: Upon hearing about the song, Diffie said, "it's really an honor" to be mentioned in the song, and that it was "flattering".
section: == Professional music career == | === 2004–2020: The Ultimate Collection and later activity ===

sentences: Later in the year, Diffie collaborated with Aaron Tippin and Sammy Kershaw on the album All in the Same Boat, and cut the single "Girl Riding Shotgun" with D Thrash of the Jawga Boyz.
section: == Professional music career == | === 2004–2020: The Ultimate Collection and later activity ===

sentences: This was followed in 2019 by a vinyl album called Joe, Joe, Joe Diffie.
section: == Professional music career == | === 2004–2020: The Ultimate Collection and later activity ===
== Musical styles ==

sentences: Musical styles ==
section: == Musical styles ==

sentences: Steve Huey of Allmusic wrote that Diffie "lent his traditional sensibilities to humorous, rock-tinged novelties and plaintive ballads."
section: == Musical styles ==

sentences: His early albums for Epic mostly consisted of ballads, but starting with Honky Tonk Attitude, he began to include more up-tempo and novelty numbers.
section: == Musical styles ==

sentences: Starting with A Night to Remember, Diffie returned to a more ballad-oriented sound; Mike Kraski, then the senior vice president of sales for Sony Music Nashville, thought that the albums before it had over-emphasized his novelty releases.
section: == Musical styles ==

sentences: Alanna Nash regularly compared Diffie's voice to that of George Jones.
section: == Musical styles ==

sentences: In her review of A Thousand Winding Roads, she contrasted the album with Mark Chesnutt's debut Too Cold at Home by saying, "While Chesnutt merely takes his inspiration from Jones, Diffie mimics Jones' delivery ...
section: == Musical styles ==

sentences: But now that he's making records himself, [his vocal imitation] drops him to the rear of the pack, as a stylist with little style of his own."
section: == Musical styles ==

sentences: She thought that Diffie began to move away from his George Jones influences on A Night to Remember.
section: == Musical styles ==

sentences: William Ruhlmann wrote that Diffie "has put together a decade-plus career in country largely on his ability to succeed" in "scour[ing] Nashville publishers for 10 good compositions in the established style", and that he was an "adequate but undistinguished singer."
section: == Musical styles ==
== Personal life and death ==

sentences: Personal life and death ==
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: Diffie was married four times.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: His first wife was Janise Parker, whom he married while in college.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: The couple had two children, Parker and Kara, then divorced in 1986.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: Parker Diffie later worked as Diffie's stage manager in the mid-2000s, and in mid-2010, he and Kara auditioned for American Idol.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: Two years after divorcing Janise, Diffie married Debbie Jones, a nurse technician.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: They had two sons, Drew and Tyler, the latter of whom was born with Down syndrome and nearly died in 1991 following complications from a tonsillectomy.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: In 2000, Diffie married Theresa (née Crump), whom he met at a concert, at the Opryland Hotel in Nashville.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: They have one daughter, Kylie, born in 2004.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: The couple divorced in 2017.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: Diffie married Tara Terpening at The Musicians Hall of Fame in Nashville in 2018.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: From 1992 to the early 2000s, Diffie held a charity concert and golf tournament benefiting First Steps, a nonprofit organization for the education of mentally  and physically impaired children.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: His contributions to this organization won him a Humanitarian Award from the Country Radio Broadcasters in 1997.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: Diffie later became a country music radio broadcaster himself, fronting a midday program for Tulsa radio station KXBL.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: On March 27, 2020, Diffie announced that he tested positive for coronavirus in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: Two days later, on March 29, he died in Nashville at the age of 61 from complications of the virus.
section: == Personal life and death ==
